Employees have no trust in the Sr. leadership team in HR, including the Executive over HR. Leaders have been put in place with very little prior leadership experience and it clearly shows. Motivation, engagement and moral are at all time lows. What once used to be a place where every HR professional in Calgary wanted to be a part of is now a place no one wants anything to do with. 

HR leaders will tell you these comments are sour grapes for those that have lost their jobs recently within Cenovus, but you don't need to look any further than the number of resignations the department see's on a monthly basis. Talk to those that have chosen to leave and a clear picture of what it is like to work there will be provided.

pros:
Cenovus has been incredibly supportive with my return from family leave.  They have accommodated my request for a graduated return and have created space and opportunity for me to work in a new and challenging role. They have also rewarded and recognized my efforts prior to taking maternity leave, which was very motivating and heart-warming. 

The team and people I connect with are astounding. People are tired, but they are doing incredible work to support change across the organization. 

This company has been very good to me and I believe it of paramount importance to share; nothing is ever all bad or all good.
cons:
Mental and physical exhaustion among employees due to the ongoing change. It's a tough place, like many energy companies to work right now, but people are trying so hard to bring team spirit and laughter to the workplace.  

This doesn't mean there isn't work to do and improvements to make - there is always room for growth. I am hopeful that we can bring about true change by being kind, honest, compassionate and building connection.

pros: Used to be lots of potential for growth. The pay is still good even with the cuts to allowances. Safety is a higher priority here than previous employers.
cons: Old boys club in management that seems to continually make and change rules for no other reason than to feel powerful. If you disagree with management you will be actively held back from advancing or simply demoted. When I got here they bragged about how there was almost zero attrition, now it's like they are doing their best to force people to quit.  Any type of memo or info on the reorganization should just be ignored, as should any timeline about it because management doesn't meet their own deadlines anyways. management flew out to tell us how they were building a new ops camp but a couple months later we get told that'll never happen and that we're moving to a different camp with even smaller rooms instead.

pros: Unfortunately not much left that makes Cenovus stand out from anyone else. My individual manager is awesome, but everyone above him is useless.
cons:
Lack of accountability. No ramifications if you don't do your job. 
Lack of leadership. Promises and no results. No experience outside Cenovus or oil and gas industry. No clue how to lead in difficult times. Wasted massive amounts of money in good times. 
Constantly in a state of re-org. Numerous (30+%) of group leads (managers) with no reports. 
Nepotism at its core. It's about who you know and who likes you. Recent promotions of many to Director/VP show a complete lack of understanding how employees are feeling (but the were "due for over a year"). Not a great message after laying off so many people. 
Processes either don't exist or are so ridiculously overwritten we are being turned into monkeys.

job_title: Facilities Project Engineer in Calgary, AB
pros: Used to have a great culture, lots of great people working there. some of that may come back in the future.
cons: The company has no direction, and in general is completely reactionary. as can be evidenced by the February statements that the company was prepared for low prices for a long period and had no plans to lay off, then in July we need to lay off 300-400, then in September, actually its 540, and once it was done in October the truth that it was actually 700. The problem is not the numbers or the layoffs, but the complete lack of a plan. in tough times you have one job, and they failed it badly.

review_title: The company is definately going through growing pains.
pros: Historically, treated it's employees well.  So, comp&ben are still competitive. Tonnes of opportunities after the Encana split. It's oilsands assets are among the lowest-cost in Canada. Focus on quality &, safety. When oil is up, they spend a lot to hire and develop New Grad's in an effort to improve management. Great working in the Bow.
cons: Trending away from treating it's employees well. Severe culture deterioration that will take years to recover. Going through cost cutting environment for 3-4 years (with no end in sight after the COP acquisition) Exec's over obsess  on oilsands & neglect their conventional assets. Have been dumping assets on the CHEAP & killing company value.

review_title: Tough times but hopefully things are turning around
job_title: Engineering Team Lead in Calgary, AB
pros: Good benefits - maybe not what they used to be, but certainly still in line with other companies.  It's not the same environment it was five years ago - people need to realize that and appreciate what they have.
cons: It's hard to see good people exited and then top management VP roles go to candidates that would never qualify for that role if their resume was among true qualified candidates. HR has to realize they can't recycle VPs into open roles and expect the ranks to accept and follow. You have people working for new unqualified leaders, and those workers carry the bulk of the work.  All HR is accomplishing is gender balancing.

pros: Some of the nicest people to work with. The camp was comfortable.
cons: Some of the worst management I experienced. No guidance. Tell you very little and get annoyed when you ask too many questions they cannot or will not answer. They love to live in a grey area so there is no black and white only on paper. Had times when they under the table to told you to break the rules but also said they will not protect you if caught. Not enough operators to do the job in certain areas.

pros: Great people to work with, a lot of talented personnel.  Great salaries and benefits, good opportunities to do volunteer work with company members. Very good work space too, with appropriate equipment and good IT support.
cons: There is a lack of direction, and a certain level of disconnect between the leadership and the technical leads, what they know and what they can do.  Many experienced people were let go in the recent cuts, and a number of them were doing a lot of the actual work, and were acting as very good mentors too. Ill-defined roles and responsibilities, overlaps, gaps, difficulty to recognize and involve correct stakeholders or decision-makers and get relevant information across. They are working on it, but this creates inefficiency and impacts work life balance of a lot of individuals.    Benefits and perks not so good anymore due to the economic environment.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Calgary, AB
pros: Company has great assets and should have a stable and strong future. One of the better Canadian grown oil-sands developers.
cons: Executive leadership and middle management is clueless on how to handle this downturn. Month to month the executive make public statements to try and boost shareholder confidence but inside they are destroying the foundation of the company. 2 years ago Cenovus was an amazing company to be a part of.. Today it is the perfect example of the emperors new clothes. If you praise the leadership and upper management for their ideas you may make the "next" cut. Such lack of communication with employees and contractors alike. Worst job in my 30+ year professional carreer. I would leave tomorrow but the ability to get a job right now is making it so hard to leave.

review_title: Not as bad as it's made out to be... Don't know where all these terrible managers are hiding
pros: Competitive salary. Plenty of opportunities to work with and learn from some really talented and smart people. Huge focus on innovation with an awesome summit every 2 years. It feels like a balance has finally been struck between shareholder returns and employee experience.
cons: Contrary to the "focus on innovation" comment, it can often be difficult to get traction for a new initiatives or innovations unless it has a high potential for cost savings. I think the IT support model and stakeholder engagement could be better across the company.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Good hard working people, good salaries, vacation, and benefits (although they are starting to get worse).  Not sure what else to say.  Just trying to get to 20 words.
cons: Stale leadership, lack of communication, lack of direction, constant re-orgs, lack of role clarity and extremely low morale.  I understand the need for cost cutting, but it seems like everything has been impacted.  Everything from jobs to benefits to Fridays off to stationairy have been drastically cut.  It's insane the hoops I have to jump through to get a notebook to do my job.  This company used to be THE place to work, but not any more.  There is a good focus on safety, but it doesn't take into account that the workload is high and everyone is doing 3 jobs now.  People are starting to experience serious burnout and it wouldn't surprise me to see a lot of people on stress leave soon.

pros: Cenovus is starting to recover from the low point of the downturn and they are hiring cautiously. Having moved to a functional model as part of their restructuring there is opportunity everywhere to help influence what this looks like as the implementation is still very much in progress.
cons:
The hiring process is painfully slow. On boarding of new staff is terrible and you are largely left to navigate an outdated online orientation alone. 
Some of the leadership have been assigned programs under the new functionality model that they do not understand introducing additional complexities for employees that are already challenged to implement a major change.

review_title: A Call to Unionize! - Come back union representatives!
pros: There is hope that the union representatives might return for another vote.  Please contact us in the field.
cons:
A few years ago, the CEO stated, "we are glad that you 'choose' to work at Cenovus".  This was when the industry was doing well.   

We are currently slowly coming out of a recovery .. and they are still saying "... just be happy you have a job!..."   

I am happy to have a job, your right.. but us highly specialised technical staff have no goodwill for this company and will leave as soon as the jobs come back.. the cost of very short thinking leadership...    CNRL leadership got it right in their approach...  

The staff in the field are ready for another union vote, so please contact us.

SHAREHOLDERS:  beware of investing as talent, which differentiates the winners and the losers in the industry , is buying time and one foot out the door.

pros: For the first few years, Cenovus had a challenging, demanding environment in which groups worked together to achieve targets.  The work was interesting and rewarding, on a professional level.
cons: In the last couple years Cenovus has undergone continual change, with initiatives poorly focused and lead.  Changes were not completed and some were revised / recreated after substantial work had been undertaken.  At the same time, from my perspective, Cenovus underwent a cultural change from an organization that was inclusive and employees were driving for the success of the company to one in which individuals are valued for their connections with upper management, above anything else and at the expense of everything else.

pros: Attractive assets, still retains a reasonable brand reputation and has hard working, we'll meaning staff in front line and lower leadership levels.
cons:
Has become highly political, with the large humber of workforce reductions over the last 18 months we have managed to almost retain a 100% of those staff members that were shrewd at aligning themselves with the right senior leadership.  This came at the cost of letting go a lot of outspoken but talented individuals.

The organization has too many layers (middle and senior management), in addition to the obvious job titles that infer leadership, there are a large number of individuals in the technical stream who are part of a 'shadow' leadership hierarchy.

pros: Decent benefits, nice offices, many hardworking good quality staff. Not much more to say good but need 20 words minimum
cons:
The place is incredibly political.  Many decisions are made for political reasons and not business reasons. 

The management team is very self absorbed and too inexperienced and it really shows.

Do not understand what senior management does.

Those with extensive knowledge and industry experience are treated badly in this organization.

Many junior staff overpromoted thus leading to poor quality inexperienced decisions.

Very clique/clubby based.  Ability has little to do little with the promotion system in this organization.

Long term asset management sacrificed for "capital efficiency " with predictable substandard results. 

Anything relating to the "functional model"

Anything relating to a JMP

review_title: Don't know what some of these folks are talking about
pros: Yes the money, benefits and 2 Friday's off per month.
cons:
Too many mangers (no leaders what-so-ever) for each project/department, no one takes responsibility for anything - just finger pointing, lack of management expertise, I never met the group leader even once in the three + years that I was there - we were even on the same floor...how crazy is that!

Very little if any for career advancement, will pay for education but nothing with any substance, made many of my colleagues cry almost on a daily basis and one of them would toss their cookies in the washroom.

pros:
•	Fantastic Assets
•	Eager to innovate
•	Environmental conscience
•	Vacation
cons:
I have lost all faith in the executive team.  They struggle to provide a vision for the company.  Their efforts are focused on the wrong areas (eg. Creating Christmas videos about their childhood & posting them on the corporate website), they could be passing budgets in a timely manner or working on properly executing layoffs.  In the last Management Proxy Circular the executive team all granted themselves “exceeds expectations”, how this is possible?  The must not be held to the same SMART (Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Reasonable, Timely) goals the rest of the employees are held too.  
The budget for training is non-existent, my opportunities for growth & learning comes from leveraging the experiences of veteran colleagues.  
Safety has taken a backseat, as a Calgary employee that travels to site I am no longer able to renew my safety tickets.

pros: Good compensation and benefits with 1st and 3rd Friday's off and ability to purchase additionaly vacation time.  Big company so there is the possibility of moving roles within the company.
cons:
Politicals rule.  Leaders are picked from the pool of other leaders friends based on their brown nosing abilities and not leadership skills consequently this company is serverly lacking meaningful leadership.  A good number of managers are more inclined to manage their own career instead of their team, so they spend more time networking and working out how to get to the next level.  

Senior management lacks vision and seems to spend a lot of time and effort creating new posters, but then forgets to actually follow up or enact change.  Recent company internal survey has highlighted the general dissatisfication of the staff, so will be interesting if they can or try to turn things around.

pros: The option to purchase vacation.
cons:
Cenovus was an amazing company when I started. However, the past few years have been terrible. While the industry has been hit hard by the downturn, their competitors have bounced back. Cenovus management has driven the company into the ground. 
Upper management keeps staff in the dark regarding all decisions leading to a lack of trust going both ways. 
They have a bloated middle management level.  These people are not the best for management roles, but the company used promotions as a reward for technical accomplishments. 
This is also the most sexist company I've ever worked for. If you are female, do not come work here! The view that females are second class is present at all levels of the company. The procedures and policies for dealing with harassment are inadequate and designed to protect the company, not the population being harassed. I thought in 2017 that the world was beyond this attitude.

pros: Decent building to work in.  Good assets, which will be valuable if oil prices increase slightly.  Did have good benefits perks but that is about to change.
cons:
No methodologies for identifying leaders.  Promotions seemingly random with little consideration.
Technical expertise not valued.  Zero mentoring of new grads or junior staff.  Constant reorganizing.  Identify layoffs are coming months in advance is demoralizing to staff.  Company will struggle to recover if oil prices increase.  I've worked at a few producers and the culture at Cenovus is by far the worst due to constant reorganizing and the resultant politicking that occurs.

pros: Cenovus was a great company to work for whereby Leadership listened and valued their employees experience and contributions.
cons: The downturn in the economy changed Cenovus for the worse. Leadership no longer valued their employees contributions and randomly selected layoffs rather than performance based. Some employees that remain with the company have much less experience and qualifications than those that were let go. Obviously it was a money issued rather than value of employee contribution. Leadership is struggling to hang on to their own jobs via whatever means necessary. Do not recommend working for them until economic condition improve and leadership is changed.

review_title: From best to worst. Too bad
pros:
Good production assets
Good operations staff and experience
cons:
Upstream organization is completely bogged down in a misdirected and irresponsible re-org.
Core people at the working level are keeping the company running with little direction from the executive which has been promoted beyond their competency.
Cenovus is trying too hard to become a different company than its peers in areas where they are surrounded by proven peer approaches. 
The Cenovus that emerged from Encana had a culture of inclusion, influence and opportunity. Now it is about boundaries and grabbing power before someone else

pros:
- Salary, benefits and vacation are excellent
- Good oilsands and conventional assets
- Potential to become a great company
cons: Executive completely obsessed with 'functional model', org charts and self promotion. Most political big oil company I've worked at in my 20 year career. Far too many managers and VP's for an organization this size. Almost every aspect of the job is following an inane process over achieving tangible results.

review_title: Cuts went too far, and are not coming back as oil prices come back up
job_title: Plant Operator in Christina Lake, BC
pros: Great people that work here
cons:
No raise in three years
Cut field operations pay, but not people in Calgary
Cut field positions
Camp food is weak at best
Very top heavy company with far too many mid-top management positions who are all fighting amongst make themselves to justify their own job
I make less than I did when hired 5 years ago.
Stock price is laughable
Calgary is destroying cultures at Foster Creek by making them go to 8 and 7 schedule and at Christina Lake by cancelling all flights from Medicine Hat, Saskatoon, Lloyd, Red Deer, Kelowna, and Cranbrook
Bonus have been declining every year I've been here
Dry camp
I see my family less as I'm travelling more to get to work.

review_title: No end in sight to morale and leadership issues
pros: Week off in December. Every Friday off in summer. There are people that work hard, have your back and make it a good place to work, but they will probably leave soon too.
cons: Too much change and significant  downsizing over last few years. Many people overworked. Low morale. Empty promises. Ineffective senior management. Those to blame for the culture issues always pointing fingers and blaming others for the poor morale.  The company is a shell of the company I used to work for and loved.

pros: A respectful, engaging and humbling group of people to work with. I am constantly impressed with the caliber of individuals I get to work with.
cons: With the downturn in the economy, the Company has made changes that many find challenging. Change is difficult and many people here are dedicated, career-long employees. Despite this, I feel morale is quite good and people are pulling together to get through it and make it a place we are all proud of.

pros: The work is challenging,  recognition is based on merit, very capable peer group and leadership team in EIS.  EIS has worked well as a team  on major projects supplier consolidation in 2016 and Deep Basin integration this year.  A lot to be proud of.
cons: I am aware in other departments of poor/incompetent leadership impacting morale of high performing staff.   Disappointing that it seems to be pervasive in Finance and SCM.

pros: Difficult to come up with 20 words that describe pros to work here...after many months of seemingly bad decisions and poor communication to the workforce t is now getting even worse with moving all of our support to Calgary - we will be spending much of our time and resources doing support work ourselves and not focused on production and safety.
cons: The company seems to be very top heavy with decisions made at head office that don't make sense to the operations sites and the people who produce oil. Many managers in head office and cuts/reductions seem to affect the field staff more pointedly than the Calgary workforce.

review_title: Lots to learn but politically very challenging
pros: Great assets, strong position in Canadian oil sands, excellent technical people. Great pay and benefits; time off policies are among the best in industry.
cons: Politically charged environment - too reliant on relationships and gut feel to make decisions. No accountability for executives and senior managers to live up to behaviours and culture expectations. Poor change leadership - trying to do too many things at once and never able to really follow through on anything.

review_title: Total reversal in culture to profit focused over employee
job_title: Panel Operator in Cold Lake, AB
pros: Competitive salary. Fly in fly out option for those who wish not to live in the Cold Lake area and don't want to be home every night.
cons: Benefits below average. Have to purchase additional vacation. Push from central management to turn Foster Creek into fly in fly out only after relocating hundreds of families to the Cold Lake area even after huge push back from employees. Communication from management very misleading with regard to acknowledging unhappy employees and bad moral. Limited progression opportunities due to ongoing cuts, and many leadership roles backfilled without being posted to other employees. No real plan communicated for negotiating new large debt load and low share price except "we're not focused on share price whatsover".

pros:
Every other Friday off
Juice in the kitchens
Pay and benefits comparable to other competitors
cons:
Nepotism very much alive here.
Stock price continues to decline.
Management not skilled in managing downturns - company too young.
The amount of spending by this company is unsustainable.
Management leans towards hiring friends, not those best qualified.
Old boys club in play - women largely disadvantaged and hardly promoted. If you are not part of it - this will be reflected in your lack of progression, and lack of bonus compared to the old boys.
The offices likely to be as empty as EnCana's soon - things can and do change quickly, the Cenovus ego is large.  
You quickly realize it is no better than any competitor out there

pros: Great vacation, good compensation and benefits, at the team level people generally get along well.
cons: What a mess. So many overlapping roles and responsibilities. Bullying still allowed by some leaders. Switch to functional model attempt caused more troubles since it has only been partially implemented. No long- term thinking or plan for what happens when oil sands can't compete on cost or carbon. No true focus on innovation to address that.

pros: The benefits and vacation time.  Frontline workers and managers are great people to work with.
cons:
Year after year asset teams beat management expectations on production and costs, yet frontline employees are passed over for recognition.  It use to be exciting to work for Cenovus but after the honeymoon phase, it's become clear that the executive team is not competent enough to manage a company.  Case in point: "Double NAV by 2015" was a corporate goal that got swept under the rug as 2015 came and went without even coming close to attaining the goal.  Meanwhile, the org structure continued to get to top heavy while fattening the wallets of senior management.

This review is not a function of market conditions, the market conditions are just magnifying the management team's shortfall's and the company's deficiencies (top-heaviness and expensive support groups).

pros: Good values (environment, health, safety etc.), the company's processes and procedures are streamlined and impressive (accounting, their intranet, communications etc.), when the industry was doing well they had great events and recognition programs.
cons: Poor leadership at the bottom and in the middle of the company. Employees are not able to give honest feedback, and leaders are threatened by more skilled workers underneath them.

pros: Comparable pay and benefits with its peers.
cons: Top heavy management with no leadership. Managers and VP's from other organizations parachuted in as "axe men" lends itself to a toxic workplace, everyone in my department is on edge waiting for the other shoe to drop. Hidden agendas, lack of clarity, and extremely poor leadership makes for a lot of head scratching. Oh and by the way, the good - ol' boys club is very alive and well at Cenovus. If your not a member your in for some tough slugging.

review_title: Great company staff moral requires attention
pros:
Great People
Great opportunities
With new acquisition we are well positioned to be a strong company for many years to come
Great salary

Hours are too long - either bring back the Friday's off or give us regular 8 hour work days.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Calgary, AB
pros: If you really need a job to keep a roof over your head and food on the table, then this place will do, but only out of sheer desparation as a last resort!
cons: I have never seen an HR department so complicit with horrendous treatment of employees.  This was so very  sad, and embarassing, and just plain cruel.

pros: Pay scales follow industry standards, good benefits ( used to be great), plenty of vacation time and Friday's off in July & August
cons: Working here has turned into a job not a joy. I used to leap out of bed to go to work. I knew that happy, intelligent, forward thinking co-workers were waiting to work with you to complete & solve the days tasks. Today co-workers are slowing down not knowing what direction to go caused by the confusion in org structures they make the choice to do nothing ( not all but many) and my work ethic has changed as a result, I am know longer convinced that management values my experience and expertise, work has become a waiting game.. Since direction is probably going to change why bother as you will most likely have to do re-work. Change can be a good thing but not when you are going through it for three agonizing years with no end in sight.

pros: descent pay, do like the one week on and one week off schedule, this allows for getaways with out burning up vacation time
cons: less then stellar camp even within Cenovus organization and the food is subpar. HR is completely oblivious to many of the employee practices that happen in the organization, absolutely no consistency in hiring, firing or promoting of staff

review_title: Good/Bad experience depends which department you work in

One of the largest Producers which makes them the big player

pros: HR has been posting on this website to improve the overall ratings under the direction of the CEO.  This started when the company won the glass door award for one of the top ten worst company to work for in North America.  Good company but this activity concerns me.
cons: I work within the HR team and HR leadership has been asked to ensure there are ‘balanced’ reviews on this site per direction from the CEO.  I am aware of two people in HR who are required to post on the site every few weeks.   It’s not right and unethical so I’m am taking the risk to disclose this is happening.

review_title: A shell of its former self ....

pros: Decent pay, benefits, bonuses and long term incentives. Some top notch technical people, especially among the senior and staff level technical ranks.

pros:

review_title: Oh, how the Mighty have Fallen
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Calgary, AB
pros: It used to be such a great place to work, and I for one could not have been more proud to say I was an employee, sadly none of the reasons why I loved it here exist any longer.
cons:
Salary: 
Salaries were pretty good when I started with the company 10 years ago, but Cenovus employees have not seen a cost of living increase to their salaries in the past 5 years. Consequently, for your average “worker bee” the salaries cannot really be considered to be that great or competitive with our peers any longer.
There are also a lot of rumors that after the looming  2018 layoffs that salaries and bonuses will still need to be cut to reduce the G&A to the level promised to shareholders by the previous CEO. These rumors were for the most part rooted in the very negative message to employees via INC. (Internal Company Website) by the COB earlier in 2017. 

L.T.I.’s:
In reality, these actually no longer exist. The multipliers for our PSU’s have been so small  in the past few years that these are inconsequential. 

Benefits:
When employees say that the Benefits are good, I don’t think they have had to use them since July 1, 2017, as the Benefits were slashed to the bone at that point. We are now at the lowest benefits tier that Sunlife offers and the few benefits we do have, we pay dearly for. 

The ability to buy vacation with “Cenovus Benefit $” is now so expensive that for a lot of employees the purchasing of additional vacation is no longer an option. A few years ago, I was able to purchase 2 weeks’ vacation, the Enhanced Benefits and both Life and Disability insurance and still have some of my “Cenovus Benefit $’s ” go into my contribution portion of the Company Savings. As of July 1st, 2017 to purchase 2 weeks’ vacation, the barebones Basic Benefits and minimal Life and Disability insurance cost me over $3000.00, so no, the benefits at Cenovus are no longer even close to being good.

Work/Life Balance:
Not as great as some people would lead you to believe.  Cenovus has a 30 minute longer base workday than most of our peers. The Calgary Cenovus staff are required to put in a minimum of 40 hour/week base + and additional 2.5 hours for our EDO’s for a total of 42.5 hours/week. Whereas our peers at CNRL, Suncor and Husky put in a 37.5 hour/week base + 2.5 hours for their EDO’s for a total of 40 hours/week.

 I think for a lot of the senior professionals, the term “Worklife Balance” should be replaced here at Cenovus by the term “Work/Life Integration”. We have lost so many staff to workforce reductions (3 rounds of layoffs @ 600+ so far, with another 700 looming in early 2018) that the workload for most has increased dramatically; leaving the only way to get it all done is by working from home using the MyVPN connection.

Cenovus traded our 1st and 3rd Fridays (which we worked back 100%) for a summer schedule of Fridays off and an extended Christmas break. I for one still do not like this arrangement. The company said they had to do this to restore faith in the Investment community because the shareholders wanted the employees to suffer along with them. 
I think what the Investment community would have preferred is to not have their investment dollars squandered by the Cenovus Executives on the Conoco deal. 

Work Environment/Employee Morale:
The morale of the average Cenovus employee has suffered irreparable damage. The work environment can be summed up in a single word, depressing….and getting worse.  This is a direct result of the looming staff reductions of yet another 700 employees. Do not believe for a moment that these additional staff reduction are to be blamed on current commodity pricing, these reductions are a direct result of the crippling/horrible Conoco Deal. What is very disheartening to me is that the previous CEO got to keep his pride in tact by being “Retired Off” with a very lucrative package while making life very stressful and difficult for the average employee. 

I feel shame should be put everyone on the Board and the Executive team that had anything to do with the extirpation of Cenovus, it used to be such a great company.

Decisions are made to make major changes to things like pay structure, benefits, vacation, work organization, etc, that usually don't save hardly any money, and sometimes cost money, they don't bother doing a cost/benefit analysis to see if it's worth implementing. Also don't seek any feed back on these decisions, they just feel they should be doing SOMETHING, if it's positive  or negative is irrelevant.  Here's a few examples:

Calgary staff and many of the field staff have had their 'flex' time reduced, which in most cases takes away a couple weeks of time off. Now instead this time is being payed out in cash, which is messed of for two reasons. First it actually cost the company money, and I thought we were all about saving money in this economy. Second, Cenovus (and Encana before it) has long presented its self as a place that values the work/life balance, a place that truly feels employees are most productive when they aren't so stressed out all the time. I know don`t know a single person who works here that didn't come to the company because that idea really appealed to them, and now Cenovus is dismantling it. 

Foster Creek site is being forced into being a camp job. Cenovus is building a brand new operations camp and will be flyiing staff to Calgary and Edmonton. Obviously this is going to cost a lot of money for the company, and also disrupt the lives of hundred of employees who currently get to go home to their and families every night. They were told to move to Cold Lake and Bonnyville, and many of them bought houses there three to five years ago when the plant was expanding. Now house prices have drop unbelievably in the last two years, and they are told they will be flying out of Calgary and Edmonton. 

Christina Lake site has had their camp pay reduced and is losing all fight hubs except Calgary and Edmonton. The  Calgary and Edmonton flights are already full,so they aren't going to be reducing the number of flights and therefor won’t save  money, also they are giving the people in the old hubs thousands of dollars in compensation each year to pay to make their own way to those cities, So it might actually cost the company more money in the end. 

The only consistency for many of these decisions is that they make people infuriated and destroy their work-​life balance, because they seldom save money, and often cost more.

pros:

cons:
Not too long ago, Cenovus Energy was a company I was proud to say I worked for. Felt as though management really cared about my well-being and although it was a big company, it had a small company feel to it. They fostered a positive culture, and they did a great job creating a "family" atmosphere in the workplace. This all changed when the downturn hit.

First off, I fully appreciate cutbacks are necessary in fiscally challenging times. In saying that, Cenovus Energy has undoubtedly handled the downturn most poorly relative to it's peers. I'd empower whomever reads this review to look-up peers to Cenovus (ex. Suncor, CNRL, MEG etc.) on glassdoor.ca and note their scores as evidence of this claim. I'll provide specific examples of this below.

Bonuses - from the time when I first started to now, there has been a movement for employee's bonuses to be paid out more based on personal performance versus company performance. Conversely, management/executive bonus compensation was transitioned to be based more on company performance versus personal performance. Typically, from conversations with several peers spanning multiples teams, it was a rare occurrence for an individual's personal score to be greater than the company score if they weren't a part of the management structure. With this in mind, when these changes were implemented, it was asked if this change was a "cost-cutting measure" to which the executive team replied that the monetary amount to be paid out on bonuses actually increased because of the change. Since it was rare for employee's personal scores to exceed the company score this would intuitively mean that management/executive bonuses increased while employee bonuses decreased. 

Salary - when the downturn hit, it was emphasized to the workforce that salaries would not be reduced resulting in Cenovus opting to cut staff instead. Like the above example, this left a lot of staff with the underlying feeling that this was because the executive/management (who made this decision) did not want to take cuts to their own salaries and would be willing to sacrifice staff to ensure their compensation remained intact. From talking to many of my fellow employees, we felt as though methods implemented by peers such as CNRL that involved tiered salary cuts were a self-less and admirable act implemented by the executive as it resulted in the executive/management having their salaries increased by the most. From talking to colleagues from CNRL on this, although this cut resulted in reduced compensation, it actually resulted in solidifying the workforce and instilling a feeling that everyone a part of that organization was in it together. Mr. Ferguson went on BNN and said it was "gut-wrenching" to lay people off and permanently alter their way of life, yet when faced with the decision to implement a similar tiered salary cut done by CNRL that involved cutting higher earner's salaries the most, he and his team opted to proceed with layoffs.

review_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
pros: Some really wonderful, caring, hard working ground level and group lead employees work for this company.
cons:
Used to be a great company to work for but the last two years of upper management decisions has driven this company into the ground.  

Problem 1: There are those in Director and VP positions who are BULLYIES.  All they care about is getting more power and they don't care who they have to step on to get it. Promotions are driven completely by favoritism and not by who is most qualified. Causing good people to leave the company.  Anyone who stands up to them is commiting carrier suicide.  

Problem 2:  The newest reorganization which employees refer to as the DISFUNCTIONAL model.  The company spent millions of dollars on an outside consulting firm, two years in paying an entire group to prep the implementation and it has been nothing but a disaster from day one.  You are left with a company where half the people are being burned out from the work load that has been dumped on them and another half who still doesn't understand what it is they are supposed to be doing.

Problem 3:  Every corporate culture upper management has tried has failed so they just keep changing it using new buzz words that are utterly meaningless, like work life balance, straight talk and the newest one "have each others back".  None of these excist when you have bullies running the show.  

Problem 4:  Not showing employees that they are valued.  Taking away our 1st and 3rd Fridays when they were earned.  Many, many other companies have flex days (not earned days true flex days).  Changes to the bonus structure.  The CEO received a score this year of exceeds expectation which came with a hefty bonus.  Employees who had the same level of performance had their bonuses reduced to a marginalized level of payout. One of the things he exceeded expectations on was reducing G&A which was accomplished by layoffs.  Just a money transfer as far as most people are concerned, from those who were laid off to the CEO's pocket.

I could go on and on with all the things that are wrong with this company.
